subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. I wish I
wasn't laughing but I have to laugh at
myself. Yet again, because I'm remaking
this monologue - a moment ago I just
completed one, and then went to check the
video and discovered that the record
button wasn't on. To the best of my
awareness, I pressed it so quickly and
came over to this chair to sit down
and make the recording that I didn't
notice that I must not have pressed the
record button on my computer screen
sufficiently. Either that or I completely
forgot, which may be a sign that I'm in the
early stages of some form of dementia or
Alzheimer's. My mother, a saintly
individual, a yoga teacher of whom I've
spoken fondly in a previous monologue,
had Alzheimers. She had a pretty serious
case of it. Her father, my grandfather,
had Alzheimer's as well. So, to be honest,
I think I'm vulnerable and it will be
interesting to see if I continue these
monologues you can watch the progressive
decline of my brain. That will be an
interesting thing to watch, because in
general, I think I do a pretty good job
of maintaining a lot of mental activity.
For the most part if I'm not having
some kind of a lapse like that, I have a
feeling that these monologues are pretty
coherent. But, it's something I need to
watch out for. Now, let me get to the
point I had made in the earlier version.
I'm going to summarize it, I'm going to go
through it a little bit faster than I
did before, because it has to do with the
Bible and the tendency of, I guess what
are called Biblical Fundamentalists to
take the Bible literally. Now,
as an undergraduate in college I studied
Biblical Hebrew. Biblical Hebrew,
incidentally, is very different than
modern Hebrew. In the course of
studying Biblical Hebrew and also taking
courses on the Bible itself, back in the
1960's, I came across a book by Julius
Wellhausen called [Prolegomena to the
History of Ancient Israel].
Wellhausen basically initiated the
modern field of Biblical Criticism. He's
the fellow who came up with the idea
that there were four different authors
to the Bible. He basically
completely demolished the idea that the
Bible was written - and when I say
the Bible I'm referring to the five
books of Moses or that are attributed to
Moses - that they are all written by
Moses, or as some would say, dictated
by God to Moses. But, Wellhausen makes it
quite clear that there were multiple
authors. His view became the
consensus view of Biblical critics. I
also want to point out at this moment
that I have an earlier interview, I'm
going to link to it now,
with Richard Smoley, the author of How God
Became God, in which he summarizes a lot
of Biblical criticism and brings it
up to date. But we can say this, certainly,
about the Bible. If we try to look
in the Egyptian records for anything
comparable to a history of Jewish slaves
in Egypt who escaped and who crossed the
Red Sea or the Sea of Reeds and were
pursued by the Egyptian army and the
Egyptian army was destroyed and the
flooding waters after the Jews passed
through. There's no records of anything
like that at all. There's barely any
reference to the ancient Hebrews, there's
one or two brief references in the
Egyptian records. So, the story of Exodus
which is so basic, so fundamental to
Judeo-Christian
mythology lacks empirical corroboration.
Not only that, take the story of Joshua
entering into the land of Canaan, coming
upon the city of Jericho and how the
walls came tumbling down. You know the
song, "Joshua Fit the battle of … Jericho…
Jericho... Jericho… Joshua Fit the battle of …
Jericho… and the walls came tumbling down."
Well, Wellhausen as I recall in his book,
which was written in the early part
of the 20th century, notes that at
that time archaeologists… I hope I have
this correct, if not forgive me
because the sources may be different… but
the facts are that archaeologists have
uncovered the walls of Jericho and the
walls of Jericho did come tumbling down,
but not overnight. The walls of Jericho
came down over a lengthy period of time,
at least a century or two. So, the idea of
the Jewish people being led into the
Promised Land by God who oversaw their
military victories is probably a fiction
made up after the fact. There are
numerous other examples. I think that as
we get past the period of Joshua and
into the actual kingdom of Israel, the
historical records become more and more
corroborated with the Biblical accounts.
But earlier accounts, not so much. I'm
inclined to think that there are
truths in the Bible, there are ethical
truths, there are spiritual truths,
there's a lot of cultural information,
an enormous wealth of cultural
information there. But, it would be a
mistake to assume that the Bible is
literally the word of God. Literally
physically true. No
way, as far as I am concerned. I know,
occasionally there are people who
comment on my monologues or on some of
the interviews, in particular on the ones
on reincarnation, and say "No, the Bible
rules out reincarnation. It says you only
live once." Well, it may say that, but I
find there's no particular reason to
take anything of that sort at face value,
when it comes not just the Bible but
to all scriptures. I find them
fascinating, I think they are very
important. There are multiple levels. I
think it's fair to say you can interpret
any scripture on seven different
dimensions at least. And there's a lot to
be gleaned from studying the scriptures.
But I am,
for your information, no where close to
taking any of that literally. One of
the viewers suggested, I think, that my
statement about God intervening in
history on behalf of the Jewish people
might represent how I really felt, for
example, about the state of Israel and
Zionism. No way. I certainly didn't
mean to imply it that way and that's why
I'm bringing up this discussion. Now,
Yuval Harari, a historian, an
Israeli historian, wrote a very popular
book, several actually, but the first of
these popular books called Sapiens is
sort of the history of the human race.
He makes a great point in it [that] one of
the defining characteristics of being
human, maybe the single most defining
characteristic of being human, is our
capacity of creating meta narratives
about events that didn't occur. Other
animals seem to be able to communicate
about real events that they
observe, but I don't believe other animals have
the capacity to create stories that
aren't true, which is unique to humans
and to human culture. These stories or
meta narratives serve a very important
role, they are the glue that holds
cultures together. The problem is to
the extent that those stories are not
true, the glue often falls apart at some
point in time, no longer capable of
holding a culture together. So, what does
this mean to you? What is the lesson here
for you and me, for us? What are the meta
narratives that you find important in
your life? What are the meta
narratives that guide you in the
world today? Do you accept them as
literally true? Is it possible that you
are holding onto a meta narrative which
is not what it appears to be, that it
should be interpreted differently than
you interpret it? Give that some thought.
And once again, thank you, thank you, for
being with me.
